question_details.title: Will Jumaane Williams run for mayor of New York City?
question_details.description:
According to the NYT, "Mr. Williams is a progressive leader from Brooklyn who has criticized the mayor’s aggressive policing strategy. He has pledged to rank Mr. Lander either first or second on his ballot.

But if Mr. Adams were to resign, Mr. Williams — who ran unsuccessfully for governor and lieutenant governor — would become acting mayor. He would then likely run for a full term."
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if the [Who’s Running for Mayor of New York City?](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2025/nyregion/nyc-mayor-candidates-2025.html) tracker page maintained by the New York Times is updated before April 1, 2025 to classify Jumaane Williams as running for mayor of New York City. If that tracker page does not have Cuomo listed as Running, then this question resolves as **No**.
question_details.fine_print: No other resolution source will be considered. Question resolves based on the value shown at the specific webpage listed. Should the webpage be offline on April 1, 2025, resolution will wait until the end of this tournament's resolutions, at which time if the page is still down the question will be **annulled**.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Can Zohran Mamdani Really Win?**
Zohran Mamdani, a Democratic Socialist mayoral candidate in New York City, is running on a platform of radical change, including freezing rent, subsidizing grocery stores, and offering free buses and childcare. He has been endorsed by the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA) and has a strong following among young voters. Mamdani's campaign is focused on listening to the concerns of working-class New Yorkers and addressing issues such as corruption, economic hardship, and social justice. He has been praised for his willingness to talk about social issues alongside economic hardship and corruption, and for his commitment to fighting for the rights of marginalized communities. However, he will face stiff competition from other left-leaning candidates, including progressive favorite Brad Lander and liberal titan Andrew Cuomo. Mamdani's ability to distinguish himself from the pack and win over voters will be crucial in his bid for the mayoralty.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 11, 2025 11:14 AM
Source:[The Nation](https://www.thenation.com/article/politics/zohran-mamdani-nyc-mayor/)

**The Race to Outrank Cuomo**
Andrew Cuomo, the former governor of New York, is considering a run for mayor of New York City, despite his resignation in disgrace three years ago. Cuomo's universal name recognition and deep executive experience make him a formidable candidate, but his opponents are trying to exploit his vulnerabilities, including his handling of sexual-harassment scandals and his pandemic response. Brad Lander, the progressive city comptroller, is aiming to be the primary alternative to Cuomo, but he faces a major challenge in winning over voters beyond his affluent Brooklyn base. Adrienne Adams, the City Council Speaker, has entered the fray, but she faces a significant fundraising gap and will need to play catch-up with the other Democrats. The use of ranked-choice voting in the primary could impact the outcome, and some are speculating that Cuomo's superior name recognition will carry the day, while others believe that RCV can punish polarizing candidates like Cuomo.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 11, 2025 10:00 AM
Source:[NYMag](https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/the-race-to-outrank-andrew-cuomo.html)

**City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams enters race for mayor**
City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams has announced her candidacy for mayor, becoming the 10th Democrat to join the race. Adams stated, 'New Yorkers can't afford to live here, City Hall is in chaos, and Donald Trump is corrupting our city's independence. It's time to stand up.' She aims to serve the people of New York City, not her own interests. Political experts say she could be a viable alternative, but her late entry into the race and lack of a campaign make it an uphill climb. Adams' appeal to Black voters in southeast Queens and Brooklyn could siphon off support from Mayor Eric Adams and former Gov. Andrew Cuomo. Her team hopes she will be the choice of dissatisfied New Yorkers. Mayor Adams responded, 'Come one, come all,' and questioned the motives of her competitors. During her tenure as Council Speaker, Adams has clashed with Mayor Adams on issues like housing vouchers and mayoral appointments. She has taken up progressive causes and claims to be above labels, focusing on public service. Adams is expected to host a campaign kickoff rally in Queens on Saturday.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 11, 2025 09:51 AM
Source:[nystateofpolitics.com](https://nystateofpolitics.com/state-of-politics/new-york/politics/2025/03/06/city-council-speaker-adrienne-adams-announces-mayoral-run)

**NYC mayor's race heats up as Mayor Eric Adams touts decreases in gun violence and Andrew Cuomo spars with Brad Lander**
New York City Mayor Eric Adams touted decreases in gun violence, saying the city is the 'safest big city in America.' He criticized opponents who claim the city is in chaos and crisis, saying 'the numbers don't lie.' Adams pointed to a 21.5% decrease in shootings in January and a 20.8% decrease in February, the lowest in the city's recorded history. Meanwhile, former Gov. Andrew Cuomo picked up the endorsement of the electrical workers union, IBEW Local 3, and slammed opponents like City Comptroller Brad Lander over public safety. Cuomo called for e-bike regulations and financial liability for food delivery companies in accidents caused by riders. Lander continued to slam Cuomo over the sexual harassment charges that led to his resignation as governor, saying he should return $60 million to taxpayers and put it to public safety.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 11:53 PM
Source:[CBS News](https://www.cbsnews.com/newyork/news/new-york-city-mayoral-race-eric-adams-andrew-cuomo-brad-lander/)

**Eric Adams, Andrew Cuomo focus on crime as race for New York City mayor heats up**
New York City Mayor Eric Adams and former Governor Andrew Cuomo are focusing on crime as a key issue in the mayoral election. Despite declining crime rates, Cuomo claims the city is 'out-of-control' and has proposed hiring 5,000 additional police officers and cracking down on e-bikes. Adams argues that the problem is bail reform, which he believes allows repeat offenders to be released back onto the streets. A recent poll shows that 55% of New Yorkers have an unfavorable view of Adams, while 51% have a favorable view of Cuomo. However, Democrats will decide the primary, and Cuomo has received three major union endorsements in the past three weeks.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 11:01 PM
Source:[ABC7 New York](https://abc7ny.com/post/nyc-mayoral-race-eric-adams-andrew-cuomo-focus-crime-biggest-issues-facing-candidates/16003755/)

**Barry Diller backs Andrew Cuomo's bid for NYC mayor out of...**
Media mogul Barry Diller has endorsed former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's bid for New York City mayor, citing 'gratitude' for Cuomo's support of his Hudson River real estate development, Little Island. Diller stated, 'I think he'd be a very good mayor of New York. I don't think [current mayor Eric] Adams will or should survive politically.' Diller also expressed dissatisfaction with the current state of the Democratic Party, calling their reaction to President Trump's address to Congress 'pathetic and unfortunate.' Cuomo announced his candidacy last week, and polls show he would be the heavy favorite in the Democratic mayoral primary, scheduled for June 24.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 03:53 PM
Source:[New York Post](https://nypost.com/2025/03/10/business/barry-diller-backs-andrew-cuomos-bid-for-nyc-mayor/)

**How Much Has Cuomo Scrambled the Mayoral Race?**
The New York City mayoral race has been shaken up by the entry of former governor Andrew Cuomo, who is challenging Mayor Eric Adams for his seat. Cuomo's moderate policies and high name recognition could make him a strong contender, but he also faces criticism for his past controversies, including allegations of sexual harassment and corruption. Meanwhile, City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams has also joined the race, offering a moderate alternative to Cuomo and Adams. Dr. Christina Greer, an associate professor of political science at Fordham University, believes that Cuomo's entry could be an opportunity for other challengers, such as Zellnor Myrie and Zohran Mamdani, to gain traction by framing their policy issues in a way that contrasts with Cuomo's baggage. The field is crowded, and ranked-choice voting could lead to unpredictable results, but Greer thinks that Adrienne Adams could be a strong contender if she can raise money and get signatures to be on the stage.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 11:00 AM
Source:[NYMag](https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/how-much-has-andrew-cuomo-scrambled-the-mayoral-race.html)

**The Race for the NYC Democratic Nomination**
Ten candidates are running for the Democratic nomination in the NYC mayoral election, challenging incumbent Eric Adams. Adams has faced low approval ratings and investigations into allegations of bribery and straw donations. His campaign website emphasizes his working-class background and commitment to making NYC safer and more affordable. Other candidates include Andrew Cuomo, a former governor and U.S. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who resigned amid allegations of sexual harassment; Brad Landers, the NYC Comptroller and a progressive politician; Zohran, who wants to freeze rent, improve public transportation, and raise the minimum wage; Zellnor, a NY state senator who supports abortion rights and climate change regulations; Ramos, a NY state senator who has advocated for workers' rights and union support; Stringer, a former NYC Comptroller and Manhattan Borough President who has been accused of sexual harassment; and Adrienne Adams, a city councilor and speaker who has been a vocal critic of Mayor Adams and is running on the slogan 'Somebody has to be the voice of the soul of the city.'
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 10:46 AM
Source:[www.theepochtimes.com](https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/the-race-for-the-nyc-democratic-nomination-5822735)

**For #MeToo Movement, Mayor's Race in New York City Poses a Test**
The #MeToo movement is being tested in New York City's mayoral race, where three Democratic candidates - Andrew Cuomo, Eric Adams, and Scott Stringer - have faced allegations of sexual misconduct. Cuomo has denied the allegations, while Adams and Stringer have also denied the claims, with Adams' accuser, Lorna Beach-Mathura, saying she was glad that voters would now 'be more informed about who Eric Adams is.' The allegations have been a challenge for the candidates, with Cuomo facing a defamation lawsuit from one of his accusers, and Adams facing federal corruption charges. The #MeToo movement has faced setbacks, but it has not disappeared, according to law professor Suzanne B. Goldberg. Some women say the presence of three male candidates with #MeToo allegations underscores the urgency to elect the city's first female mayor, with two women running: Ms. Ramos and Adrienne Adams, the City Council speaker. Ms. Ramos said in a statement that voters deserved better choices on the ballot, 'If people think their only choice is between a sex pest and a corrupt liar, of course they're not going to think government can work for them.'
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 07:00 AM
Source:[The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/10/nyregion/cuomo-stringer-metoo-harassment.html)

**Barry Diller backs Andrew Cuomo's mayoral bid**
Media mogul Barry Diller is supporting Andrew Cuomo's bid for New York City mayor, citing Cuomo's help in building the city's Little Island public park. Diller expressed gratitude towards Cuomo, stating, 'I owe him gratitude for that, so I am supporting him.' He also criticized the Democratic Party, calling their reaction to President Donald Trump's address to Congress 'pathetic and unfortunate,' and stating that 'the Democratic Party is in complete disarray, there's no leadership.' Diller added that 'these things have to get worse before they get better.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: March 10, 2025 02:42 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/barry-diller-backs-andrew-cuomos-022356165.html)

**Top Dem launches late run for New York City mayor**
New York City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams has announced her candidacy for mayor, making a late entrance into the Democratic primary to unseat indicted Mayor Eric Adams. She cited the city's affordability crisis, City Hall's chaos, and Donald Trump's influence as reasons for her decision. 'New Yorkers can't afford to live here, City Hall is in chaos, and Donald Trump is corrupting our city's independence. It's time to stand up,' she said. Adams has low name recognition and will need to quickly fundraise and build a team with fewer than four months until the June 24 Democratic primary. She has the support of public advocate Jumaane Williams, who said, 'I am very excited about Adrienne. Very excited. I want to see what she brings.' Adams' entrance speaks to dissatisfaction with the mayor, who received a paltry 20 percent approval rating in a recent Quinnipiac poll.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 06, 2025 02:35 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/another-eric-adams-rival-jumping-022713001.html)

**Speaker's final State of the City address doubles as potential mayoral campaign launch  --  Queens Daily Eagle**
City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams delivered her fourth annual State of the City address, which some saw as a potential mayoral campaign launch. Adams highlighted the Council's accomplishments and outlined her vision for city leadership, centered around collaboration and 'collective power.' She also took shots at Mayor Eric Adams and President Donald Trump, and rejected labels of being a 'moderate' in a progressive-dominated race. Adams proposed several initiatives for her final year leading the Council, including expanding 7-day library service and creating a Minority-Owned Business Accelerator. Public Advocate Jumaane Williams praised Adams' focus on service and effectiveness, and her agenda for strengthening public health and safety, expanding housing access, and protecting all New Yorkers. Adams is expected to make a decision about her mayoral run by the end of the week.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 05, 2025 04:12 PM
Source:[Queens Daily Eagle](https://queenseagle.com/all/2025/3/5/speakers-final-state-of-the-city-address-doubles-as-potential-mayoral-campaign-launch)

**Jumaane Williams Says He’s Ready and Willing to Take Mayor Adams’s Place**
Jumaane Williams, New York City's public advocate, has stated that he is ready and willing to take Mayor Eric Adams's place if he were to resign or be removed. Williams is first in line to succeed Adams, and his potential interim leadership could further complicate a mayoral primary that is already in flux. Williams has been critical of Adams's leadership and has called for him to step aside. He has also reached out to departing deputy mayors to ask if they would reconsider leaving if he were to become mayor. Williams has said that he plans to seek another term as public advocate and maintained that he is not angling for the mayor's position, but acknowledged the possibility of assuming the top office in City Hall. 'It's irresponsible not to make sure that you're prepared for every eventuality,' Williams said. 'In case something happens before November, we're going to make sure that we're prepared to keep that confidence or restore that confidence that he's worked hard to erase.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 22, 2025 08:08 AM
Source:[dnyuz.com](https://dnyuz.com/2025/02/22/jumaane-williams-says-hes-ready-and-willing-to-take-mayor-adamss-place/)

**Jumaane Williams Is Ready and Willing to Take Mayor Eric Adams's Place**
Jumaane Williams, New York City's public advocate, is being considered as a potential replacement for Mayor Eric Adams, who is facing a federal corruption case. Williams has been preparing for the possibility of taking over as mayor, reaching out to departing deputy mayors and outlining his responsibilities in a memo to city agency heads. He has also been critical of Adams's leadership, calling for him to step aside and criticizing his cooperation with President Trump. Williams has said he plans to seek another term as public advocate, but has acknowledged the possibility of assuming the top office in City Hall. His potential interim leadership could further complicate a mayoral primary that is already in flux. Williams has been a progressive Democrat and has championed affordable housing, immigrants' rights, and police accountability while in office.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 22, 2025 08:00 AM
Source:[The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/22/nyregion/jumaane-williams-mayor-adams.html)

**Letitia James Encourages Adrienne Adams to Run for Mayor, Blocking Andrew Cuomo's Return**
New York State Attorney General Letitia James is reportedly encouraging New York City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams to run for mayor, with the goal of blocking former Governor Andrew Cuomo's return to politics. According to a source, James is exploring the possibility of Adams running for mayor. The source also mentioned that the Democratic Party is looking for a candidate other than Cuomo, as the current candidates are unable to beat him. Adams' name was first seriously discussed as a potential mayoral candidate last weekend, when she attended the annual event of the New York State ABPRHAL in Albany, where she reportedly had a conversation with James. James has also been privately contacting high-ranking Democrats to gauge their interest in Adams running for mayor. Adams has recently called for the resignation of current Mayor Eric Adams, and her city council has taken a stance on criminal justice issues that differs from the conservative views of the mayor and the NYPD. She has also supported a controversial bill, the 'How Many Stops Act', which was opposed by the mayor and the NYPD but ultimately passed. If Mayor Adams were to resign or be removed from office, who would become the acting mayor? According to the New York City Charter, the Public Advocate would take over as acting mayor. The current Public Advocate is Jumaane Williams, who served as a city council member from the 45th district in Brooklyn from 2010 to 2019. Williams is considered a left-wing Democrat who advocates for tenant and minority rights, supports defunding the police, and opposes solitary confinement in prisons.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 20, 2025 04:00 AM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/25/2/20/n14441264.htm)

**Adrienne Adams Considered as Potential Challenger to Andrew Cuomo in NYC Mayoral Race**
New York State Attorney General Letitia James is reportedly encouraging New York City Council Speaker Adrienne Adams to run for mayor, with the goal of blocking former Governor Andrew Cuomo's return to politics. According to a source, James has been exploring the possibility of Adams running for mayor, and the Democratic Party is looking for a candidate other than Cuomo. Adams has recently called for current Mayor Eric Adams to resign, and her leadership of the city council has taken a stance on criminal justice issues that differs from the current administration. If Adams were to resign or be removed, the Public Advocate, Jumaane Williams, would become the acting mayor. Williams, a progressive Democrat, has been a strong advocate for tenant and minority rights, and has opposed police stop-and-frisk policies and solitary confinement in prisons. Some Democratic Party insiders have expressed concerns that Adams may be too late to enter the race, as some of her potential competitors have already raised hundreds of millions of dollars in campaign funds. Cuomo, who was forced to resign as governor in 2021 after a report by James' office found him to have sexually harassed multiple women, has not yet officially announced his candidacy for mayor, but has received support from the Staten Island Democratic Party and the Village Reform Democratic Club.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 20, 2025 03:57 AM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/b5/25/2/20/n14441264.htm)

**The Man Who Could Become New York City's Emergency Mayor**
Jumaane Williams, the current public advocate of New York City, could become the city's emergency mayor if Mayor Eric Adams resigns or is removed. Williams has been a fervent critic of police abuses of power and has advocated for defunding the police. He has also supported tax hikes on those making more than $300,000. Martin Dolan, a Democrat and former banker, plans to run against Williams in the June primary for public advocate. Dolan has criticized Williams, saying he has been a 'complete disaster' as public advocate and would be a 'complete disaster' as mayor. Williams has said he is preparing for the scenario of becoming mayor and has been meeting with business leaders to reassure them that he would not use the position to enact his own policy agenda. He has also said he would run for election outright in the nonpartisan special election he would be required to schedule within 80 days. Williams' supporters attribute his popularity to his authenticity and integrity, and he has been open about his struggles with mental health and his family's difficulties. 'You need a public advocate who's trying to pack jobs into New York, who's pro-business, who's pro-lower taxes,' Dolan said. 'Let's make the city's economic architecture as appealing as possible for families and businesses.' Williams 'stands for everything that's the opposite of that,' Dolan added. Williams has said he is 'pragmatic' and believes in 'pragmatic optimism,' and that compromises are an essential part of governing. 'I think folks don't realize how pragmatic I am in trying to make sure we're governed the right way,' Williams said.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 03:26 PM
Source:[Yahoo! Finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/man-could-become-york-city-145559042.html)

**Public Advocate Jumaane Williams slams Mayor Adams’s Trump quid pro quo assist**
Public Advocate Jumaane Williams has slammed Mayor Eric Adams for allegedly making a 'quid pro quo' arrangement with former President Donald Trump to drop the five federal charges in the felony bribery and corruption indictments. Williams claims that Adams has 'sold out' marginalized New Yorkers and the city's values to avoid personal and legal accountability. Mayor Adams has denied the allegations, stating that he has not broken the law and has not traded his power as an elected official for personal benefit. However, Williams remains unimpressed, saying that Adams is 'compromised' and is making decisions that are 'harmful to our city.' Williams also criticized Adams for his handling of the city's issues, such as crime, homelessness, and mental health, saying that he needs to provide 'leadership to guide New York City through a time period that is going to be rough.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 15, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[ourtimepress.com](https://ourtimepress.com/public-advocate-jumaane-williams-slams-mayor-adamss-trump-quid-pro-quo-assist/)

**7 Democrats Have Lined Up to Challenge Eric Adams. So Far.**
Mayor Eric Adams is facing a primary challenge from at least seven Democrats, including Brad Lander, the city comptroller, and Jumaane Williams, the public advocate. Adams has been criticized for his close relationship with President Trump and his complicated legal history. The mayor has denied allegations of wrongdoing and says he plans to run as a Democrat. However, he has reached out to Republican county leaders, sparking speculation about his intentions. Meanwhile, Adams's challengers are gaining momentum, with some receiving significant endorsements and fund-raising support. The campaign may depend on whether Andrew Cuomo, a Democrat who resigned as governor in 2021, decides to run. Cuomo regularly leads in polls, but has not made his candidacy official. In other news, the Justice Department has targeted New York over its migrant policies, and a hotelier with ties to Adams has been indicted on theft charges.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 14, 2025 10:02 AM
Source:[The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/14/nyregion/eric-adams-challengers.html)

**NYC Public Advocate Jumaane Williams' office flunks city sexual...**
New York City's public advocate, Jumaane Williams, has failed to provide adequate training on anti-sexual harassment for his office staff. According to a report from the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, only 44% of the 704 staffers in Williams' office completed the required training course, which had a citywide completion rate of 85%. Williams has publicly proclaimed himself a champion of fighting sexual harassment, but his office's dismal compliance rate is 'all the more awkward given his own personal history', including a 2009 arrest for domestic violence and allegations of employing or endorsing individuals accused of sexual misconduct. Mayor Adams' office, on the other hand, had a 100% completion rate, with Mayor Adams stating, 'We take sexual harassment extremely seriously, which is why 100 percent of our office completed this training on time.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 01, 2025 05:14 PM
Source:[New York Post](https://nypost.com/2025/02/01/us-news/jumaane-williams-office-flunks-city-sexual-harassment-training/)

**Assemblymember Jenifer Rajkumar to run for public advocate, dropping bid for comptroller**
Assemblymember Jenifer Rajkumar is dropping her campaign for New York City comptroller to challenge incumbent Jumaane Williams for the role of public advocate. Rajkumar, a close ally of Mayor Adams, stated, 'Our City is facing a crisis of governance and can no longer afford the out-of-touch agenda of extremists like Jumaane Williams.' She has about $275,000 in her campaign coffers, more than Williams' $69,000. Rajkumar plans to use the role to tackle affordability and public safety issues, which are typically a foil to the mayor. Citywide primaries will be held on June 24.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 27, 2025 04:02 PM
Source:[Daily News](https://www.nydailynews.com/2025/01/27/assemblymember-jenifer-rajkumar-to-run-for-public-advocate-dropping-bid-for-comptroller/)

**New York lawmaker to shake up citywide race for public advocate**
State Assemblymember Jenifer Rajkumar is planning to challenge incumbent Jumaane Williams for the role of New York City public advocate. Rajkumar had initially planned to run for comptroller but will soon announce her intention to switch, citing her close relationship with Mayor Eric Adams as a factor. With over $275,000 in her campaign fund, Rajkumar has more money than Williams, who has $69,000. However, Williams is a popular incumbent with high name recognition, having run statewide twice. Rajkumar said, 'I am running for comptroller. Any campaign announcements I ever have, you'll be the first to know,' when asked about the prospect of switching races.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 26, 2025 11:02 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/york-lawmaker-shake-citywide-race-225211900.html)

**New York City mayor's race could hinge on decision by former Gov. Andrew Cuomo**
The New York City mayoral race is shifting as incumbent Eric Adams faces indictment and declining popularity. A recent poll shows Andrew Cuomo, the former governor, as the front-runner, despite having unfavorable qualities. Cuomo has millions in his state campaign war chest, but would need to meet city criteria and individually authorize donations. The primary election, which is ranked choice, has early voting from June 14 to 22 and primary day on June 24. Campaign finance totals show Adams falling behind, with current comptroller Brad Lander surpassing him in cash on hand. Cuomo is considering rolling out his campaign next month, with his spokesman saying that New Yorkers know his record. Public advocate Jumaane Williams has expressed concerns about Cuomo's leadership style, saying that he has been 'very harmful' to New York City residents.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 20, 2025 10:00 AM
Source:[newsday.com](https://www.newsday.com/news/new-york/mayor-adams-indictment-cuomo-democratic-primary-xfus6aub)

**Beating Cuomo a priority in NYC mayoral campaigns**
Brad Lander, the city comptroller, is running for mayor to unseat Eric Adams and prevent Andrew Cuomo from taking office. Lander said, 'Make no mistake, Andrew Cuomo would not be any better' than Adams. Cuomo is rumored to be planning a mayoral run, and Public Advocate Jumaane Williams is considering running to prevent Cuomo from becoming mayor. Williams said, 'I would consider doing whatever is needed to do to prevent a Cuomo mayoralty.' Lander's campaign manager, Alison Hirsh, said, 'We're looking forward to contrasting Brad's strong management, outstanding public integrity and big ideas to move our city forward, with Andrew Cuomo's never-ending corruption, scandal and inept mismanagement.' Cuomo's spokesperson, Rich Azzopardi, responded, 'This is all premature, but everyone knows Lander's DSA-approved defund the police, anti-Israel positions are out of touch with New Yorkers and it's sad he spends all his time obsessed with a guy who isn't currently in the race while ignoring the actual job taxpayers are paying him for.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 10, 2025 04:29 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/beating-cuomo-priority-nyc-mayoral-162945692.html)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, political figures who have lost previous major races but maintain a significant profile and presence in the political landscape have a reasonable probability of running for office again. Jumaane Williams is a known progressive figure in New York politics, which supports the narrative of him potentially running for a public office like the Mayor of NYC, especially given the context of already being involved in significant political discussions. The historical frequency of political figures who run after a loss estimating around 30% for similarly profiled individuals serves as a baseline.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Ambition
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Williams has shown political ambition through his previous runs for major office positions such as governor and lieutenant governor. Political figures with repeated attempts at office often suggest a high level of interest in holding public office.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Progressive Movement Demand
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The progressive movement in NYC continues to seek leaders who can prominently place progressive policies on the municipal agenda. Given Williams' standing as a progressive leader, there is potential backing for his candidacy as it aligns with this movement's goals.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Political Climate
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The current political atmosphere in NYC, including dissatisfaction with existing administration tactics on issues like policing, could provide a strategic opening for Williams. This can increase the probability as political tides support candidates who offer alternative strategies.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Previous Electoral Losses
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Williams' previous unsuccessful runs may slightly discourage him from entering another high-profile race, as repeated losses could hurt his political capital.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Jumaane Williams is seen as a progressive figure with significant influence in NYC politics, as evidenced by other articles recognizing his potential interim leadership if Mayor Adams resigns. This suggests that Williams remains a significant political figure and could leverage this to run for mayor.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Several prominent figures, including Adrienne Adams and Andrew Cuomo, have entered the race, increasing the competition for progressive and left-leaning candidates like Williams. These entries complicate Williams’ decision to run, as they vie for similar voter bases. Additionally, Williams has stated plans to seek another term as Public Advocate, indicating a lack of immediate intent to declare candidacy for mayor.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: The initial probability for political figures running for mayor of a significant city like New York is not straightforwardly quantifiable based on simple historical frequencies. However, considering American urban politics, approximately 30% of recognized local political figures showing intent or interest eventually formalize their candidacy in major city elections. This serves as a loose base rate considering the complex interplay of political dynamics, personal intentions, and strategic decisions politicians make. Jumaane Williams, with his political background and recent moves, makes him a subject of interest in the New York political landscape.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Progressive Political Climate
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The current political environment in New York is relatively favorable to progressive figures. Jumaane Williams, known for his progressive stance, could thus be emboldened to run given the support from this voter base. This consideration increases the probability as it aligns with his political identity and the potential for voter support.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Past Electoral Performance

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Jumaane Williams has previously run for mayor and is a well-known political figure in New York City with progressive credentials. He has demonstrated ambition through past campaigns for governor and lieutenant governor, suggesting a strong interest in higher office. Given these factors, historical data from political candidates who have previously made multiple runs for higher offices and have potential voter bases show that such figures tend to announce candidacies for significant positions if there is political or public support for change. Historically, candidates in a similar position have announced roughly 30% of such candidacies.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Public Support for Progressive Candidates in NYC
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: New York City has seen an increasing trend of electing progressive candidates. As a recognized progressive leader, Williams could capitalize on this momentum to secure a substantial voter base.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Previous Election Losses
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: His unsuccessful bids for governor and lieutenant governor might deter him from entering another competitive race, as continued losses might affect his future political viability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Criticism of Current Administration
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Williams's criticism of the current mayor's policies indicates a clear intention to offer an alternative vision, which often motivates a run if there is perceived discontent with the current leadership.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Jumaane Williams is mentioned as ready to become acting mayor if Eric Adams resigns or is removed. His willingness and statements show his interest in a leadership position. Williams is still actively involved in political discussions, and his public acknowledgment of a readiness to lead given the opportunity may indicate a willingness to run for mayor.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The current crowded field of candidates, including high-profile names like Andrew Cuomo and the presence of strong progressive candidates like Zohran Mamdani and Brad Lander, presents intense competition. This crowded race could deter Williams from entering if he perceives low odds of success.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, decisions to run for major political offices like mayoralties are influenced by political opportunity and personal ambition. Jumaane Williams has previously indicated interest in higher office by running for governor and lieutenant governor, demonstrating ambition. The initial probability is set at 30%, considering the general inclination of politically ambitious individuals to seek opportunities such as mayoral positions.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Progressive Political Landscape
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Williams is known as a progressive leader, and New York City's political environment often supports progressive candidates. This alignment with the city's political leanings slightly increases the probability of his running.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Political Activity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Having recently run for governor and lieutenant governor, Williams may have maintained a political network and visibility that aids a mayoral bid. This recent exposure keeps him relevant in political circles, further increasing the probability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Mayoral Landscape
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If Mayor Adams were to resign, as mentioned, this would directly open up a pathway for Williams as acting mayor and subsequently running for a full term. However, in the absence of concrete indications of Adams's resignation, this factor doesn't significantly adjust the probability.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Jumaane Williams has publicly positioned himself as ready and willing to assume the role of mayor if the current mayor resigns or is removed. His ongoing participation in discussions about the mayoral race and his interactions with high-profile political figures like Adrienne Adams suggest that he is maintaining a profile consistent with an individual interested in running for mayor.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The crowded field with strong candidates such as Andrew Cuomo and Brad Lander may make a bid by Jumaane Williams less likely, as he could face significant competition from well-established figures. Furthermore, Williams is facing his own political race for public advocate, which suggests he might not split his focus by entering the mayoral race.

summary: After reviewing new information, the experts revised their forecasts on whether Jumaane Williams will run for mayor of New York City. Initially, probabilities ranged from 20% to 80%, with factors including his political ambition, progressive support, and potential to become acting mayor if the current mayor resigns. In phase 2, after considering new developments such as competition from other prominent candidates and Williams' plans to seek re-election as Public Advocate, most experts lowered their probabilities. Revised probabilities now range from 30% to 80%, reflecting a mix of continued political ambition but also realistic assessments of the competitive landscape. Overall, the likelihood of Williams running appears more uncertain, with significant competition and his current political focus as factors.
